Title: Former FAA administrator and airline pilot provides analysis on midair collision in D.C. area
Description: Steve Inskeep speaks with former Federal Aviation Administrator Randy Babbitt about the midair collision in Washington, D.C.

Title: What we know about the midair crash near Washington, D.C.
Description: Authorities believe there were no survivors in the accident, which happened as a regional passenger jet was attempting to land Wednesday night at Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport. (Image credit: Kayla Bartkowski)

Title: U.S. and Russian figure skaters are among the victims of the D.C.-area plane crash
Description: The plane that crashed near Washington, D.C., was carrying an unknown number of passengers from the figure skating community, including Russian husband-and-wife world champions. (Image credit: Chris Cole)

Title: Plane, Black Hawk helicopter collide near D.C. And, Trump's plans for Guantánamo
Description: An American Airlines plane and a Black Hawk helicopter collided near Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport last night. And, President Trump plans to use Guantánamo as a waystation for deportees. (Image credit: Andrew Harnik)

Title: Authorities believe there are no survivors after a midair crash in Washington, D.C.
Description: Authorities in Washington, D.C., say they believe no one survived a midair collision between a regional airliner and a U.S. Army helicopter.

Title: 3 Israeli and 5 Thai hostages freed in Gaza in exchange for Palestinian prisoners
Description: The exchange is part of a deal between Israel and Hamas that will see a total of 33 hostages returned to Israel in exchange for around 1,900 Palestinian prisoners and detainees. (Image credit: Mostafa Alkharouf)

Title: After fires, LA students yearn to get back to school, and a normal life
Description: The historic fires in Los Angeles meant many students lost homes, schools, or both. Now, as some schools reopen, families are trying to find routine. (Image credit: Jireh Deng for NPR)

Title: Trans community fears Trump's actions will upend legal precedent on prison protections
Description: One of President Trump's first executive orders impacts transgender inmates incarcerated in federal facilities. It's just one in a series of actions signed by Trump that target the trans community. (Image credit: Ben Curtis)

Title: Trump's pick for intel chief, Tulsi Gabbard, faces her confirmation hearing
Description: Among the topics likely to come up at the hearing: her 2017 meeting with Syrian President Bashar al-Assad, her friendly positions toward Russia and her push to drop charges against Edward Snowden. (Image credit: Kevin Dietsch)

Title: Trump's FBI director pick, Kash Patel, faces confirmation hearing
Description: Kash Patel, President Trump's pick to run the FBI, answers questions Thursday in a public hearing before the Senate Judiciary Committee. (Image credit: Anna Moneymaker)

Title: Criminal records of Jan. 6 rioters pardoned by Trump include rape, domestic violence
Description: Dozens of Jan. 6 defendants who received pardons from President Trump had past criminal convictions for charges including rape, manslaughter, domestic violence and drug trafficking. (Image credit: Julio Cortez)

Title: Morning news brief
Description: Rescuers search for survivors after midair collision in D.C. area, Trump plans to hold criminal migrants deported from U.S. at Gitmo, some pardoned Jan. 6 rioters have lengthy criminal records.

Title: First responders search for survivors following midair collision in D.C. area
Description: A regional jet with 64 people aboard collided in midair with an Army Black Hawk helicopter as it was approaching a runway at Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport on Wednesday night.

Title: Legal centers for migrants kick into high gear as Trump ramps up immigration policies
Description: Legal centers across the country are preparing migrants without legal status for various scenarios as the Trump administration tries to ramp up immigration raids, detentions and deportations.

Title: Trump plans to hold up to 30,000 criminal migrants deported from the U.S. at Gitmo
Description: President Trump says he plans to use a migrant holding facility at the U.S. naval base in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, to house up to 30,000 criminal migrants deported from the United States.President Trump says he plans to use a migrant holding facility at the U.S. naval base in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, to house up to 30,000 criminal migrants deported from the United States.

Title: Immigrant couple in Chicago plans for potential deportation scenarios
Description: An undocumented couple in Chicago, whose baby is a U.S. citizen, prepare for potential deportation and plan to keep the family together no matter what President Trump does.

Title: Aviation safety consultant provides latest analysis on midair collision in D.C. area
Description: We get analysis from an aviation safety consultant on the midair collision between an American Airlines plane and Army Black Hawk helicopter on Wednesday night in the Washington, D.C. area.

Title: President Trump's order to suspend foreign aid hitting Afghanistan particularly hard
Description: President Trump's order to suspend foreign aid is impacting Afghanistan, where anxiety over food supplies have partly pushed up prices. The Taliban says dozens of charities have had to halt work.

Title: How to rebuild smarter after the LA wildfires when housing is in such short supply
Description: The Los Angeles wildfires have many cities asking whether it's safe to build new housing in risky areas. But limiting construction is tough when there's a housing shortage.

Title: The Kingdom Behind Glass
Description: Who owns stolen art? Today on the show, the bloody journey of a Benin Bronze from West Africa to the halls of one of England's most elite universities — a tale of imperialism, betrayal, and the making of the modern world.

Title: Trump order cracks down on antisemitism and could deport foreign student protesters
Description: The executive order directs government agencies to use all available tools to prosecute or remove perpetrators of antisemitic harassment and violence, especially on college campuses. (Image credit: Andrew Harnik)

Title: Trump says U.S. will send 'worst criminal illegal aliens' to Guantánamo Bay
Description: The president says up to 30,000 criminal migrants deported from the United States could be housed at the facility in Cuba, but it wasn't immediately clear how the plan would be implemented. (Image credit: Ramon Espinosa)

Title: American Airlines plane, Blackhawk helicopter collide midair near D.C.-area airport
Description: Radar tracking sites show the passenger jet appears to have fallen into the frigid Potomac River. Officials at Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport say all takeoffs and landings were halted. (Image credit: Ting Shen)

Title: Greenland, Still Not For Sale. And the Mona Lisa Gets Its Own Room.
Description: Even if Greenland were for sale, buying the Artic territory would be complicated. And French President Emmanuel Macron promises to renovate the Louvre, which is falling into disrepair.

Title: What would RFK Jr. mean to HHS?
Description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. faced senators today in a contentious confirmation hearing to serve as Health and Human Services Secretary under President Trump. He's a former Democrat — turned independent presidential candidate — turned Trump loyalist.He's also someone who has pushed vaccine misinformation, something he was repeatedly questioned about during his confirmation hearing on Wednesday.HHS is a massive system that oversees everything from the Food and Drug Administration to vaccine funding to the Affordable Care Act. What do we know about how Robert F. Kennedy, Jr. would run it? For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.orgEmail us at <a href=...

Title: Trump orders Education, Labor and other departments to enhance school choice
Description: The president directed several departments to submit plans for using federal funds to expand school choice. (Image credit: Jim Watson)

Title: The future of passports with the X gender marker
Description: As the state department freeze passport applications with the X gender markers, what are the implications for both current and future passport holders?

Title: Visiting a Russian air base to see how Moscow will fare after the fall of the regime
Description: Russia lost a key ally when the Syrian President was ousted by Islamist rebels last month. NPR visited a Russian air base in western Syria to examine how Moscow will fare under Syria's new rulers.

Title: Trans servicemember says 'we will do the best we can' amid Trump proposed military ban
Description: NPR's Scott Detrow speaks with Col. Bree Fram, an openly transgender member of the U.S. Space Force, about President Trump's calls to remove transgender service members from the military.

Title: On the ground in Gaza: Red Cross' role in hostage and prisoner exchanges
Description: As prisoner and hostage exchanges happen in Gaza, we hear about the International Red Cross's experience in facilitating this work.

Title: Trump's pick for Commerce Secretary is Howard Lutnick. Here's what to know
Description: The billionaire Wall Street CEO fielded questions about tariffs, China's AI progress, broadband access, allegiance to Trump and the revival of American mining and semiconductor production. (Image credit: Rod Lamkey)

Title: As global tensions rise, so do fears of new nuclear testing
Description: For nearly 30 years, the world's major powers have observed a voluntary moratorium on nuclear testing. But with tensions rising around the globe, some fear that could soon change.

Title: Photos: Celebrations commence the Year of the Snake
Description: For many, the Lunar New Year is a time to reflect on people they have lost. But it's also a time to set intentions and welcome the new energy of the future. (Image credit: Greg Baker/AFP)

Title: Trump ends extension of temporary protected status for hundreds of thousands of Venezuelan migrants
Description: The move to revoke the extension of temporary protected status would make hundreds of thousands of Venezuelans eligible for deportation. (Image credit: Manuel Balce Ceneta)

Title: Trump's Mideast envoy visits Gaza before meeting with Netanyahu
Description: Steve Witkoff helped negotiate the Israel-Hamas ceasefire deal. His visit to Gaza pn Wednesday was the first by a senior U.S. official in more than a decade. (Image credit: Hasan Eslayeh)

Title: Hegseth strips Milley of his security detail, orders investigation into his conduct
Description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth has ordered an investigation into retired general Mark Milley — who often clashed with President Trump — and determine whether he should be reduced in rank. (Image credit: Anna Moneymaker)

Title: Ahmed al-Sharaa, who toppled Assad, is named Syria's interim president
Description: Sharaa was already de facto head of Syria's government ever since a coalition of rebel fighters swept through most of Syria and ousted Assad's regime. (Image credit: Ali Haj Suleiman)

Title: New York becomes the first state to close schools for Lunar New Year
Description: It's the first time New York students will have the day off for the Lunar New Year since a new state law was signed in 2023. In 2024, the holiday fell on a Saturday. (Image credit: Michael M. Santiago)

Title: Trump signs first bill of his second presidency, the Laken Riley Act, into law
Description: The bill is named for a Georgia nursing student who was killed last year by a Venezuelan man without legal status who had a criminal record. (Image credit: Pedro Ugarte)

Title: DOJ asks to dismiss case of 2 men indicted for allegedly helping Trump hide documents
Description: The DOJ asked a federal court to dismiss its case against two men indicted for allegedly helping Trump conceal classified documents. Prosecutors dropped Trump from the case after his election win. (Image credit: Anna Moneymaker/Getty; Rebecca Blackwell/AP)

Title: Fearing encounters with ICE, tribal leaders offer guidance to their members
Description: Tribal leaders are advising members on what to do if they're approached by federal law enforcement. The guidance follows what tribal leaders call concerning encounters with immigration officials. (Image credit: Alex Brandon)

Title: The Doomsday Clock has never been closer to metaphorical midnight. What does it mean?
Description: The Doomsday Clock now stands at 89 seconds to midnight, the closest to catastrophe in its nearly eight-decade history. Here's a look at how — and why — it's moved. (Image credit: Kayla Bartkowski)

Title: Two ways Trump aims to reshape government. And, how U.S. children are doing in school
Description: President Trump's actions this week reveal his broad effort to reshape the federal government. And, the new Nation's Report Card shows the pandemic's impact on education nearly five years later. (Image credit: Kent Nishimura)

Title: RFK Jr. says he'll fix the overdose crisis. Critics say his plan is risky
Description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. survived heroin addiction and says that if confirmed as head of the Department of Health and Human Services, he'll build treatment 'farms' to help people recover. (Image credit: John Nacion)

Title: 66 million years ago, a fish chewed up and spit out food. It's now a fossil in Denmark
Description: The fossil was found at a cliff in Denmark. Fossilized vomit is called regurgitalite, and it's a type of trace fossil, which tells scientists about an organism's daily life. (Image credit: Sten Lennart Jakobsen)

Title: Step inside the secret lab where America tests its nukes
Description: A thousand feet beneath the desert, the United States conducts experiments to verify that its weapons work. But some fear a live test could come soon.

Title: Nearly 5 years after schools closed, the nation gets a new report card
Description: There's some good news in math, mostly bad news in reading and lots of questions about why students are still struggling. (Image credit: Newsday LLC)

Title: New Orleans clears homeless encampments near stadium ahead of Super Bowl
Description: As New Orleans prepares to host the Super Bowl, state authorities have moved people from homeless encampments near the stadium to a temporary shelter. Advocates aren't happy with how it went down.

Title: Homeless encampments near stadium in New Orleans removed ahead of Super Bowl
Description: As New Orleans prepares to host the Super Bowl, state authorities have moved people from homeless encampments near the stadium to a temporary shelter. Advocates aren't happy with how it went down.

Title: Morning news brief
Description: Trump trying to dramatically reshape federal government, RFK Jr. faces Senate confirmation hearings for HHS secretary, national assessment on reading and math shows students struggling post-pandemic.

Title: U.N. warns that Democratic Republic of Congo conflict could spill into regional war
Description: In the Democratic Republic of Congo, Rwandan-backed rebels have overrun the city of Goma, sparking concerns at the U.N. of a wider regional war.

Title: Martin Gordon, Anglican bishop of Goma, calls for peace in the DRC
Description: NPR's Michel Martin speaks with Martin Gordon, the Anglican bishop of Goma, who fled before rebels advanced into the city in the Democratic Republic of Congo. Today, he is issuing a call for peace.

Title: Late revered French Catholic priest Abbé Pierre accused of sexual abuse
Description: Revered French Catholic priest and humanitarian Abbé Pierre has been accused of rape and sexual assault nearly 20 years after his death, leading France to grapple with his legacy.

Title: Former OMB official reacts to Trump's attempt to freeze federal loans and grants
Description: NPR's Steve Inskeep asks former associate director at the Office of Management and Budget, James Capretta, what it means that the Trump administration tried to pause federal loans and grants.

Title: National assessment on reading and math shows students still struggling post-pandemic
Description: New results from a national assessment of reading and math sheds new light on how K-12 students are doing nearly 5 years since COVID-19 triggered historic disruptions in learning.

Title: With Gaza ceasefire, Yemen's Houthi rebels halt attacks on ships in the Red Sea
Description: With the ceasefire between Israel and Hamas in Gaza, Houthi rebels in Yemen have stopped missile attacks on ships in the Red Sea and have also released a shipping crew held hostage for over a year.

Title: Several people are feared dead in a stampede at massive festival in India
Description: Millions continued to throng the site even as police urged them to avoid the area. Deadly stampedes are relatively common around Indian religious festivals, where large crowds gather in small areas. (Image credit: Deepak Sharma)

Title: Why members of two of EPA's influential science advisory committees were let go
Description: Acting EPA Administrator James Payne sent an email to members of the agency's Science Advisory Board and the Clean Air Scientific Advisory Committee informing them that both are being 'reset.' (Image credit: Justin Sullivan)

Title: Trump asks SpaceX to 'go get' two stranded ISS astronauts. They're not stranded.
Description: Two NASA astronauts flew to the International Space Station in June on Boeing's Starliner capsule. The test flight was planned for eight days but technical troubles forced the capsule to return empty. (Image credit: AP)

Title: See you latte: Starbucks plans to cut 30% of its menu
Description: Starbucks is trying to fix falling sales by changing its vibe back to coffee-house roots. The new CEO says parts of the plan, like free non-dairy milk, are helping bring people back. (Image credit: Godofredo A. Vásquez)

Title: NJ Attorney General joins suit to stop Trump's federal grant freeze
Description: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly speaks with New Jersey Attorney General Matthew Platkin about his plans to block a federal funding freeze President Donald Trump ordered Monday. (Image credit: MANDEL NGAN/AFP via Getty Images)

Title: The Long Walk Home to Northern Gaza
Description: NPR Producer Anas Baba walks home to Northern Gaza, as Palestinians are allowed to return as part of a ceasefire deal with Israel and Hamas. And, a month after the fall of the Al-Assad regime, Syrians are euphoric, but face a shattered economy and fragile security.

Title: Trump's callout of Russia's Vladimir Putin is raising eyebrows
Description: President Trump is threatening sanctions and tariffs on Russia if Putin doesn't reach an agreement to end the war in Ukraine. Some are surprised, considering Trump's affinity for the Russian leader.

Title: Neymar leaves Saudi team to return to his first soccer club in Brazil
Description: Neymar struggled through physical injuries for most of his time in the Middle East, with a previous ACL rupture that kept him sidelined for a year. (Image credit: Yasser Bakhsh)

Title: The Louvre will be renovated and the 'Mona Lisa' will have her own room
Description: French President Emmanuel Macron laid out an ambitious plan for a 'reimagined, restored and expanded' Louvre. An art critic says Macron is aiming for another success after restoration of Notre Dame. (Image credit: Bertrand Guay/Pool)

Title: A look at the massive fire fighting effort in L.A. — from the sky
Description: One thing that was impossible to miss -- as fires raged through L.A. -- was the fight from the air. Officials say it might have been the largest number of aircraft at a fire event, ever.

Title: Syria's new government is trying to rebuild. First it must keep the lights on
Description: Syria's new de facto government faces a host of challenges. One of its most pressing is also one of its most basic: keeping the lights on.

Title: Promised U.S. visas, tens of thousands of Afghans are in limbo with Trump order
Description: White House executive orders have effectively frozen all evacuations of American allies in Afghanistan. Veterans from across the political spectrum are pushing to change this.

Title: The company planning a successor to Concorde makes its first supersonic test
Description: Denver-based Boom Technology's XB-1 demonstrator plane hit Mach 1.122 — 750 mph. It's the first independently developed supersonic jet. The company is also working on a supersonic passenger airliner.

Title: Did you plan to buy a home -- but found renting is cheaper? We want to hear from you
Description: As mortgage rates and home prices have risen, the rent vs. buy calculation has changed. If you're renting when you'd planned to buy, tell us your story. (Image credit: Matt Rourke/AP)

Title: Trump issues order to ban transgender troops from serving openly in the military
Description: The executive order speaks of transgender identity in sweeping and dismissive terms, and sets the stage for a policy that is more restrictive and punitive than the ban from Trump's first term. (Image credit: Kent Nishimura)

Title: DeepSeek: Did a little known Chinese startup cause a 'Sputnik moment' for AI?
Description: Buzz around DeepSeek built into a wave of concern that hammered tech stocks on Monday. (Image credit: Andrey Rudakov)

Title: Not your average baby shark: An aquarium welcomes a pup from an all-female tank
Description: Yoko the swell shark was born in a habitat of all-female sharks who hadn't seen a male in years. The aquarium has two possible explanations — and hopes to get confirmation in the coming months. (Image credit: Morgan Nix)

Title: DOJ fires officials who investigated Trump. And, what to know about DeepSeek
Description: At least a dozen Justice Department employees involved in prosecuting President Trump have received dismissal notices. And, why China's DeepSeek AI is such a big deal. (Image credit: Kevin Dietsch)

Title: News for Trump: Denmark's last envoy to Greenland says U.K. may have first dibs
Description: Denmark's last minister for Greenland says Britain once claimed right of first refusal over the territory — because of its proximity to Canada, which Britain once ruled. (Image credit: Felipe Dana)

Title: Ukraine uses souped-up Soviet-era weapons to defend a vital river from Russia
Description: As Ukraine's line of defense grows thin, this unit is using a modernized Soviet-era vehicle to stop Russian forces from crossing the river and taking Kherson. (Image credit: Anton Shtuka for NPR)

Title: Big reveals are unlikely in Trump-ordered Kennedy and MLK document drops, experts say
Description: Historians say the Trump-ordered release of more information on the killings of President John F. Kennedy, Robert F. Kennedy and Martin Luther King Jr., could be interesting but unlikely to rewrite history. (Image credit: AFP)

Title: Danish leader on European tour as nation moves to boost presence around Greenland
Description: Denmark's prime minister went on a tour of European capitals Tuesday as Europe faces what she called 'a more uncertain reality' and her country moves to strengthen its military around Greenland. (Image credit: Antti Aimo-Koivisto)

Title: Morning news brief
Description: Legal status of 1.4 million migrants at risk after 'humanitarian parole' ends, DOJ leaders move to fire at least 12 who investigated Trump, stocks fall after Chinese company releases competitive AI.

Title: Legal status of over 1.4 million migrants at risk after 'humanitarian parole' ends
Description: President Trump has ended so-called humanitarian parole for people from Cuba, Haiti, Venezuela, and Nicaragua, jeopardizing the legal status of nearly 1.5 million immigrants in the U.S.

Title: Fatal beating of inmate prompts calls for reform at New York's state prison system
Description: New York's state prison system is under scrutiny after guards fatally beat an inmate in December, prompting protests and calls for reforms.

Title: Family members of 9/11 victims weigh in on possible plea deals for defendants
Description: A federal appeals court will hear arguments today over whether the alleged mastermind of the 9/11 attacks and two accomplices should get plea deals. Family members of 9/11 victims weigh in.

Title: A group of former U.S. spies opposes building a new casino near D.C. Here's why
Description: A new casino could be built less than 20 miles west of Washington D.C. More than 100 former spies and intelligence officers oppose its construction due to concerns it could jeopardize state secrets. (Image credit: Getty)

Title: Tennessee students march for gun reform as governor focuses on other priorities
Description: After a shooting in Nashville last week, students are again marching on the Tennessee Capitol, but the governor has called the special session to focus on school vouchers and immigration enforcement.

Title: New Syrian leadership destroying Captagon, an addictive drug made by the Assad regime
Description: Rebel fighters who are now part of Syria's new de facto government have been destroying large shipments of Captagon, an addictive drug that was mass produced by the ousted Assad regime.

Title: Trump Immigration Policies End Refugee Programs and Begin Deportation Flights
Description: Thousands of Afghans Are in Limbo as the U.S. Halts Its Refugee Program. Columbia Agrees to Accept Migrant Flights After Tariff Threats. (Image credit: Andrew Harnik)

Title: Justice Department moves to fire at least 12 officials who investigated Trump
Description: In termination letters sent to more than a dozen officials, acting Attorney General James McHenry wrote that he did not believe they 'could be trusted to faithfully implement the President's agenda.' (Image credit: Kevin Dietsch)

Title: National Science Foundation freezes grant review in response to Trump executive orders
Description: The National Science Foundation has canceled all grant review panels this week. It's unclear how long the pause could last. (Image credit: Drew Angerer)

Title: What Syria looks like a month after the fall of the regime
Description: After the sudden fall of the Syrian regime in December, Syrians are still euphoric but grappling with a shattered economy and fragile security.

Title: How districts are responding after Trump cleared the way for immigration arrests at schools
Description: President Trump put an end to a policy that restricted federal agents from making immigration arrests at certain locations, including schools. It's already affecting school staff, kids and parents. (Image credit: Julia Demaree Nikhinson)

Title: Thousands of Palestinians return to north Gaza for the first time amid ceasefire
Description: The Israeli military has unblocked roads going north in Gaza, allowing many Palestinians to return for the first time since the beginning of the war. Including NPR's Anas Baba, who fled 15 months ago.

Title: Hegseth has signaled he may halt efforts to fight extremism in the military
Description: For years, Republicans in Congress have been trying to cut Pentagon initiatives to fight extremism in the military. Now, the Trump administration may be poised to end those anti-extremism efforts.

Title: Immigration raids are sending migrants into a deep panic, advocates say
Description: The Trump administration has quickly ramped up ICE immigration raids across the country. In the Chicago area, some immigrant communities are already changing their everyday routines.

Title: Oath Keepers founder no longer banned from D.C., U.S. Capitol
Description: The judge said it was 'reasonable' the Justice Department interpreted Trump's Jan. 6 commutations to cover the defendants' prison sentences and wipe away their terms of supervised release. (Image credit: Mandel Ngan)

Title: The last of the escaped South Carolina lab monkeys have been recovered
Description: The female rhesus macaques staged an escape from the Alpha Genesis Primate Research Center in South Carolina last year. (Image credit: Jean-Francois Monier)

Title: Afghans who helped the U.S. are in dangerous limbo after Trump's order on refugees
Description: Tens of thousands of Afghans who risked their lives working for the U.S. government or military are now in limbo after the Trump administration issued two executive orders targeting refugees. (Image credit: Robert Nickelsberg)

Title: Elon Musk faces criticism for encouraging Germans to move beyond 'past guilt'
Description: Musk's comments came two days before International Holocaust Remembrance Day and right after he was criticized for making what many viewers interpreted as a Nazi salute during an inauguration speech. (Image credit: Sean Gallup)

Title: Auschwitz survivors mark Holocaust Remembrance Day 80 years after liberation
Description: Monday's ceremony in Poland is regarded as the likely last major observance of Auschwitz's liberation that any notable number of survivors will be able to attend, due to their advanced ages. (Image credit: Oded Balilty)

Title: The First State of Being' and 'Chooch Helped' win top children's book awards
Description: This year's Caldecott medal went to a book about an older sister frustrated when her baby brother 'helps.' The Newbery went to a middle-grade tale about a time traveler at the turn of the century.

Title: Trump's immigration orders are a blueprint for sweeping policy changes
Description: President Trump began his immigration crackdown with a flurry of executive orders. Immigration experts say they lay out how he hopes to transform enforcement at the southern U.S. border and beyond. (Image credit: Charly Triballeau)

Title: A plan to save TikTok. And, Palestinians return to northern Gaza
Description: Inside the Trump administration's plan to save TikTok. And, tens of thousands of displaced Palestinians are returning home to devastated northern Gaza for the first time in over a year. (Image credit: Omar Al-Qattaa)

Title: Auschwitz holds observances on the 80th anniversary of the death camp's liberation
Description: Elderly camp survivors, some wearing striped scarves that recall their prison uniforms, walked to the the Death Wall, where prisoners were executed. Across Europe, officials were pausing to remember. (Image credit: Oded Balilty)

Title: Thousands of Palestinians begin returning home to a devastated Gaza
Description: The long trek home by Palestinians comes as mediators helped end twin crises over ceasefires in Gaza and Lebanon. (Image credit: Omar Al-Qattaa)

Title: A Republican court candidate in North Carolina wants to toss out thousands of votes
Description: More than 80 days after Election Day, a race for a seat on the North Carolina Supreme Court remains unresolved. That's because the Republican candidate is contesting some 65,000 ballots. (Image credit: Chris Seward)

Title: Morning news brief
Description: Palestinians return to Gaza City for first time in over a year as ceasefire holds, Florida Gov. DeSantis calls lawmakers to special session on immigration, Chiefs and Eagles to face off in Super Bowl.

Title: President Trump moves ahead with plans to deport record numbers of migrants
Description: President Trump is moving ahead on his promise to deport record numbers of migrants. NPR speaks with John Sandweg, former acting director of ICE in the Obama administration, to discuss Trump's plans.

Title: Palestinians return to Gaza City for first time in over a year as ceasefire holds
Description: Ceasefires in Israel's conflicts with Hamas and Hezbollah hit snags. A disagreement over a hostage prevented Palestinians' return to northern Gaza. In Lebanon, Israeli troops clashed with protesters.

Title: Afghans seeking asylum in U.S. left in limbo after Trump suspends refugee program
Description: After Trump halted the U.S. asylum system, thousands who were waiting to reach safety after years of vetting found themselves in limbo. They include Afghans who worked with the U.S. in Afghanistan.

Title: President Trump calls for Jordan and Egypt to accept more Palestinian refugees
Description: President Trump is calling for Jordan and Egypt to accept more Palestinian refugees. NPR's Leile Fadel discusses the issue with Khaled Elgindy, a visiting scholar at Georgetown University.

Title: Trump wants federal workers back the office, meaning longer days and added expenses
Description: Many federal workers live in Baltimore and usually work from home. Now they're being told they have to commute to Washington, D.C., every day, meaning longer days and added expenses.

Title: White House says Colombia agrees to take deported migrants after Trump tariff threat
Description: The White House claimed victory in a showdown with Colombia over accepting flights of deported migrants from the U.S. on Sunday, hours after President Donald Trump threatened various sanctions. (Image credit: Fernando Vergara)

Title: Rwanda-backed rebels claim to have seized key city in Congo
Description: Rwandan backed rebels have entered the city of Goma, a key city in neighboring Democratic Republic of Congo. Could the mineral rich region be in danger of tipping into all out regional conflict? (Image credit: Moses Sawasawa)

Title: One doctor's harrowing, monthlong visit to Gaza, in the days before the ceasefire
Description: Dr. Mimi Syed spent one month in Gaza providing medical care for residents there. She documented her time via voice memos for NPR.

Title: What a week of ceasefire looks like in Gaza
Description: President Trump says he wants Egypt and Jordan to resettle Palestinians from Gaza as a shaky ceasefire holds between Israel and Hamas.

Title: Israeli troops fire on displaced Palestinians hoping to return to homes, killing 2
Description: Meanwhile, close to the Israeli border in southern Lebanon, Israeli troops opened fire on protesters, killing 22 and injuring 120, according to Lebanese officials. (Image credit: Omar al-Qattaa)

Title: DeSantis faces pushback by fellow Republicans on his call for an immigration session
Description: Republican leaders in the state legislature say they support President Trump's pledge to combat illegal immigration but want to deal with it and other issues identified by DeSantis on their schedule, not his. (Image credit: Evan Vucci)

Title: Rain gives LA wildfire relief but officials warn of mudslides and toxic ash
Description: Rainfall could cause mudslides in area burned by wildfires, with officials warning residents of toxic material from debris and ash. (Image credit: Frederic J. Brown)

Title: South Korean prosecutors indict impeached President Yoon Suk Yeol over martial law
Description: South Korean prosecutors on Sunday indicted impeached President Yoon Suk Yeol on rebellion in connection with his short-lived imposition of martial law. (Image credit: Jeon Heon-Kyun/AP)

Title: Ceasefire agreement holds for a second week after Hamas and Israel swap
Description: Hamas releases four female Israeli soldiers and Israel releases 200 Palestinian prisoners, as the ceasefire agreement brokered by the U.S., Egypt and Qatar holds into its second week.

Title: Trump is threatening more sanctions against Russia if it fails to negotiate on the war
Description: As President Trump threatens new sanctions against Russia, the Russian economy thrives despite previous measures that failed to deliver the intended bite.

Title: Police departments are divided on enforcing the Laken Riley Act
Description: Congress has passed the Laken Riley Act, facilitating the detention and deportation of people in the country illegally when they've been charged with crimes. What remains to be seen is how much local police and jails will do to help this effort.

Title: He was forced to dig mass graves in Syria. His own brother could be one of them
Description: Mass graves are being discovered in Syria, testament to the horrors committed under the now ousted leader Bashar al Assad. The story of one man forced to help dig some of those graves.

Title: Churches have a long history of being safe havens — for immigrants and others
Description: For centuries, houses of worship have served as havens for people needing refuge — and, in recent decades, sanctuary from the U.S. government. (Image credit: Jeff Haynes/AFP)

Title: International peacekeepers killed as fighting rages around eastern Congo's key city
Description: Fighting with M23 rebels in eastern Congo has left at least 13 peacekeepers and foreign soldiers dead. M23 has made significant territorial gains in recent weeks, encircling the eastern city of Goma. (Image credit: Moses Sawasawa)

Title: Reckoning with the Assad Regime's 'Machinery of Death'
Description: The fall of Syria's leader in December opened the doors to a vast network of detention centers and prisons across the country, uncovering further evidence of the true scale of killings under former president Bashar al-Assad. On this episode of The Sunday Story, NPR's Ruth Sherlock takes us to a notorious prison where thousands were detained and killed, and she visits a suspected mass gravesite outside Damascus. Description: A group of 18 state attorneys general signed on to a lawsuit filed Tuesday seeking to block the administration's move, describing it as unconstitutional. (Image credit: Paul Ratje)

Title: A rare blizzard blasts the Deep South, as arctic air brings a hard freeze
Description: A winter storm prompted a National Weather Service office in Louisiana to issue a first-ever blizzard warning. The storm is causing dangerous conditions from Texas to North Carolina. (Image credit: Gerald Herbert)

Title: At least 66 people killed in a fire at a ski resort in northwest Turkey
Description: A fire raged through a popular ski resort south of Istanbul early Tuesday. The deadly fire broke out during a school holiday when the area's hotels are packed. (Image credit: IHA)

Title: Trump's pick for U.N. ambassador is Elise Stefanik. Here's what to know
Description: Elise Stefanik was a key defender of then-President Donald Trump during his impeachment proceedings and she later grilled university presidents over what she described as antisemitism. (Image credit: Andrew Harnik)

Title: Murdoch's News Corp offers Prince Harry settlement to resolve years-long lawsuit
Description: Rupert Murdoch's team made the offer to resolve the hacking suits from Prince Harry and a British lawmaker as a trial was to begin. A settlement could help Washington Post CEO Will Lewis. (Image credit: Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images)

Title: Ex-Georgia prosecutor on trial for hindering Ahmaud Arbery's murder investigation
Description: Former district attorney Jackie Johnson is accused of interfering with the police investigation into the shooting death of Ahmaud Arbery, nearly five years after he was murdered while jogging. (Image credit: Michael Hall)

Title: Morning news brief
Description: Trump begins his first full day in office, Trump kicks off a slew of immigration-related executive actions, and Trump pardons all defendants charged and convicted over the Jan. 6 U.S. Capitol attack.

Title: Here's what to expect from President Trump's first full day back in office
Description: Here's what to expect from President Trump's first full day in office, as well as a recap of the executive actions he took on Monday.

Title: Chicago immigrant residents are in Trump's sights. The mayor says he'll defend them
Description: Chicago Mayor Brandon Johnson says the city will defend residents 'whether you're undocumented, whether you are seeking asylum or whether you're seeking a good paying job.' (Image credit: Erin Hooley)

Title: Chicago Mayor Johnson discusses how his city is preparing for 'mass deportation' plan
Description: NPR's A Martínez asks Chicago Mayor Brandon Johnson how his city is preparing for the so-called mass deportation raids now that Donald Trump is back in office.

Title: What Biden's preemptive pardons for family members could mean for presidential powers
Description: Before leaving office, President Biden issued preemptive pardons for five family members. Legal expert Kim Wehle discusses the move and what it means for future presidential powers.

Title: Midwest schools struggling to serve students experiencing housing instability
Description: A public radio investigation has found that Midwest schools are struggling to serve students who experience housing instability, despite a federal law intended to ensure equal access to education.

Title: Ex-Georgia prosecutor on trial for hindering Ahmaud Arbery's murder investigation
Description: Trial begins in Brunswick, Ga. for a former district attorney accused of interfering with the police investigation into the shooting death of Ahmaud Arbery, nearly five years after he was murdered while jogging in a residential neighborhood.

Title: President Trump unveils a number of new immigration-related policies
Description: President Trump kicked off a slew of executive actions related to immigration in a signing ceremony at the Oval Office on Monday evening. Hear the latest on on those policies.

Title: Palestinians in Gaza return to Rafah to find a city of rubble and ash
Description: Palestinians get a first glimpse at the destroyed southern city of Rafah in Gaza after Israeli troops withdrew following the ceasefire agreement with Hamas.

Title: President Trump signs executive orders revoking federal DEI guidelines
Description: President Trump has revoked federal DEI programs by executive order. NPR's A Martinez talks with the former head of diversity initiatives at the U.S. State Department about the programs she oversaw.

Title: Presidents Trump issues pardons to some 1,500 Jan. 6 rioters
Description: President Trump issued pardons and commutations to every defendant charged and convicted in connection with the Jan. 6, 2021 attack on the U.S. Capitol, which injured more than 140 police officers.

Title: After truck attack, New Orleans residents push for car-free areas in French Quarter
Description: After the New Year's truck attack on Bourbon Street in New Orleans that killed 14 and injured dozens more, residents there are pushing to make parts of the French Quarter a pedestrian-only zone.

Title: Taliban announce release of two Americans held in Afghanistan in a prisoner exchange
Description: Afghanistan's Taliban government announced on Tuesday the release of two Americans in a prisoner exchange. (Image credit: Anna Corbett/AP)

Title: Ohio State defeats Notre Dame 34-23 in college football championship game
Description: Ohio State dominated most of the night, and all through the playoffs (Image credit: Brynn Anderson)

Title: Trump orders end of humanitarian parole for migrants of four countries
Description: Under the Biden administration, migrants from embattled countries could apply for entry due for humanitarian reasons, without having to attempt to cross into the U.S. illegally. (Image credit: Eric Gay)

Title: Trump offers long-promised pardons to some 1,500 January 6 rioters
Description: On the campaign trail, Trump regularly featured the stories of Jan. 6 defendants he labeled 'hostages' and 'patriots.' (Image credit: Samuel Corum)

Title: Trump revokes Biden's order for federal agencies to promote voter registration
Description: President Trump has reversed an executive order by former President Joe Biden that calls for federal agencies to promote voter registration. (Image credit: Sean Rayford)

Title: Trump is back and ready to change America
Description: Donald Trump returns to Washington newly empowered. The Republican party has remade itself in his image. The Supreme Court has granted him sweeping immunity for his official actions. And, unlike last time, he narrowly won the popular vote.And Trump is prepared to exercise his new power almost immediately. He's pledged to sign an unprecedented wave of executive actions – many of which will be challenged in court.These actions include one making it U.S. policy to recognize only two biologically distinct sexes – male and female. And his administration would end birthright citizenship — a right explicitly protected by the Constitution.President Donald Trump's executive actions could make fundamental changes to some of the foundations of American government....

Title: What to know about Trump cryptocurrency meme coins
Description: The meme coins yo-yoed in value as Trump took office. Here is what you should know about the coins and cryptocurrency's future under the Trump administration. (Image credit: Mark Humphrey)

Title: First Palestinian detainees released in ceasefire deal
Description: Monday marks the first full day of a new ceasefire in Gaza. Sunday night, Israel released 90 Palestinian prisoners and detainees hours after Hamas handed over three Israeli hostages.

Title: A Los Angeles 14-year-old helps other teens after the fires
Description: A 14-year-old Los Angeles girl is helping teenagers who lost everything in the fires try to recover some sense of normalcy. Her effort to collect new clothes, shoes and beauty products has gone viral with celebrities chipping in.

Title: How Trump's inauguration speech length compares to previous presidents'
Description: Trump's second inauguration speech came out to 2,885 words — considerably longer than his 2017 address, though shorter than the off-the-cuff remarks he gave to supporters after being sworn in Monday. (Image credit: Lithograph, Charles Fenderich/Education Images)

Title: The Wars Trump Inherits
Description: As President Trump takes office he inherits two international conflicts in which the United States is deeply involved. On the campaign trail he said he would be able to end the war between Russia and Ukraine. Last month he said there would be 'hell to pay' if Hamas and Israel did not reach a ceasefire and hostage release deal before he assumed office. A temporary and fragile ceasefire began on Sunday. We hear from NPR correspondents in Israel, Russia and Ukraine to hear about those countries' expectations for the Trump presidency.

Title: Strong Santa Ana winds hitting fire-ravaged Los Angeles -- again
Description: Nearly two weeks after the start of two of the most devastating wildfires to hit the Los Angeles area, Southern California is under an extreme fire risk warning again. (Image credit: Mario Tama)

Title: Texas could join Louisiana with a law to require the Ten Commandments in classrooms
Description: Similar proposals are in multiple states after a court ruling in 2022, though opponents say the move would impose one religious view on people with different religious traditions (Image credit: Paul Weber)

Title: Trump reinforces use of his 'Remain in Mexico' policy
Description: The policy, which was created and implemented during the first Trump administration in 2019, resulted in tens of thousands of migrants waiting for extended periods in Mexico. (Image credit: Patrick T. Fallon)

Title: Trump is expected to announce 10 executive actions on immigration upon swearing in
Description: President-elect Donald Trump is set to announce a series of executive actions on immigration after he is sworn in on Monday.

Title: Austin Tice's mother returns to Syria in search for son
Description: For the first time in a decade, Debra Tice, the mother of missing American journalist, Austin Tice, returns to Syria to find news of her son. (Image credit: Omar Sanadiki)

Title: Thousands who came to see Trump's inauguration now won't get to see it in person
Description: Thousands of visitors came to Washington, D.C., to see Trump's inauguration but won't get to see the ceremony in person after it was moved indoors. We get an inauguration day view from the streets.

Title: President Biden pardons Fauci, Milley and members of Jan. 6 Panel
Description: In a statement, Biden said the pardons 'should not be mistaken as an acknowledgment that any individual engaged in any wrongdoing.' President-elect Trump has criticized many officials Biden pardoned.

Title: Trump promised dozens of actions on immigration on Day 1. Here's what we know
Description: Trump campaigned on border security promises, and he and his allies argue that his electoral win is an endorsement of his upcoming actions on the issue. (Image credit: John Moore)

Title: Prince Harry's case against Rupert Murdoch's British tabloids goes to trial
Description: A trial begins Tuesday over complaints filed by Prince Harry and a senior British lawmaker against Rupert Murdoch's tabloid newspapers. The trial carries high stakes on both sides of the Atlantic. (Image credit: Kin Cheung/AP)

Title: What to know about Ohio State, Notre Dame and college football's championship game
Description: That the Buckeyes and the Fighting Irish, two of the sport's most storied teams, are squaring off in the title game is a TV executive's dream — and a fitting end to the first-ever 12-team playoff. (Image credit: Alex Slitz)

Title: Georgia Sen. Raphael Warnock talks about MLK Jr.'s teachings from Atlanta
Description: Georgia Sen. Raphael Warnock is also a pastor at Atlanta's Ebenezer Baptist Church, where MLK Jr. held the same position. Warnock talks about what he's learned about Rev. King's teachings there.

Title: What Latinos in two Massachusetts communities are saying about Trump's return
Description: Many Latinos hope Trump will help them economically, but some immigration lawyers say those in the U.S. without legal status should worry. Hear what Latinos in two Massachusetts communities are saying.

Title: How do people in war zones feel as Trump takes office?
Description: President-elect Trump has promised to end two foreign conflicts. NPR correspondents in Israel, Russia and Ukraine asked people about their hopes and fears as Trump takes office.

Title: What to expect today as Trump takes the oath of office for a second time
Description: President-elect Trump will get sworn in today for his second term in the White House. We preview what we know about the day.

Title: Village People founder says everybody can enjoy their music, Republican or Democrat
Description: Victor Willis of the Village People says their music is for everyone, defending the group's choice to perform at Trump's inaugural celebrations as a message of inclusivity. (Image credit: Andrew Chin)

Description: A ceasefire between Israel and Hamas has gone into effect. Three women were returned to Israel after more than a year in captivity, and families of 90 Palestinians celebrated the release of prisoners.

Title: What we can expect from Trump's second term in office
Description: President-elect Trump's first stint in the White House included policies and positions that broke with tradition, like threatening to pull out of NATO. What can we expect in his second term?

Title: The science behind the FDA ban on food dye Red No. 3
Description: On Wednesday, the Food and Drug Administration announced it is banning the dye called Red No. 3, a food dye additive in many processed foods, like sodas, sweets and snacks. Recently, it and other dyes were linked to behavior issues in children. But high levels of Red No. 3 were linked to cancer in rats decades ago. So why is the ban happening now? Senior editor and science desk correspondent Maria Godoy answers our questions about Red No. 3 and other dyes that may replace it. Plus, how should parents think about feeding their kids products that may contain Red No. 3 before the ban takes affect.Questions, story ideas or want us to dig into another food science issue? Title: At least 80 people killed in northeast Colombia as peace talks fail, official says
Description: Officials said the attacks happened in the Catatumbo region near the border with Venezuela, following the government's failed attempts to hold peace talks with the National Liberation Army. (Image credit: Fernando Vergara)

Title: Photos: Families reunite as the Israel-Hamas ceasefire takes effect
Description: After 15 months war, a ceasefire between Israel and Hamas took effect on Sunday morning. (Image credit: Mussa Qawasma)

Title: Local meteorologists could face layoffs amid new initiative with The Weather Channel
Description: The new initiative will be rolled out across 27 stations and feature 'additional visual storytelling capabilities,' Allen Media Group says. (Image credit: Chance Yeh)

Title: Social Vidoes: Far from the front lines, Ukrainians fight a war to preserve their culture
Description: In the Transcarpathia region, some locals embrace a traditional lifestyle and cultural identity. After surviving Soviet threats, now they fear Russian President Vladimir Putin seeks to erase their culture.

Title: Heavy snow and frigid temps put 70 million in the U.S. under winter storm warnings
Description: Residents along the East Coast, from the Northern Plains to the tip of Maine, are bracing for several inches of snow on Sunday followed by dangerously cold temperatures. (Image credit: David Zalubowski/AP)

Title: Joe Biden's complicated legacy
Description: When he ran for office in 2020, President Joe Biden vowed to turn the page on then president Donald Trump. But it's Trump who is returning to the White House for a second term in office. We speak with NPR's Asma Khalid, who covered the Biden administration, on the legacy he leaves behind. Title: Israelis react to the ceasefire deal going into effect 15 months after the war began
Description: We look at how the ceasefire deal between Hamas and Israel is being received in Israel, where protests over domestic politics have continued throughout the war.

Description: We assess the first hours of a ceasefire between Israel and Hamas- and the mood in Gaza- after more than 15 months of war

Title: Gaza ceasefire deal set to go into effect with the release of 33 hostages

Description: NPR's Ayesha Rascoe speaks with Mars Tekosky, who lost the home she and her family had recently renovated in Altadena, California due to wildfire.

Description: We'll look at how some leaders in some of the countries that are key U.S.-trading partners have prepared for the new Trump administration.

Title: Ceasefire goes into effect in Gaza, Israel says, after initial delay
Description: The Israeli government announced the ceasefire with Hamas would take effect at 11:15 local time, nearly three hours after the originally scheduled time for hostilities to cease. (Image credit: Bashar Taleb)

Title: Steve Bannon says MAGA populism will win — as Trump is surrounded by billionaires
Description: Former Trump adviser Steve Bannon says he doesn't believe the president-elect will listen to 'tech oligarchs' over the right-wing populist movement that helped him secure another White House term.

Title: Many doctors don't discuss sex after cancer. But survivors wish they would
Description: Questions about sex and intimacy often go unanswered for people with cancer. It's a glaring problem, especially for the growing number of young people being diagnosed. (Image credit: ‎)

Title: 33 hostages are expected to be released by Hamas as part of a ceasefire with Israel
Description: There are men, women and children on the list of 33 to be released from Gaza. Two are U.S. citizens. Israel is set to free hundreds of prisoners in exchange for them.

Title: This Virginia program helps former foster youth get degrees, at any age
Description: Great Expectations was designed to help people who grew up in foster care get their two-year degrees. And unlike many programs for former foster youth, there are no age limits. (Image credit: Shaban Athuman)

Title: Gaza ceasefire begins after delay as Hamas names hostages to be released Sunday
Description: A long-awaited ceasefire in Gaza began after a three-hour delay as Hamas named the three female hostages it plans to free later on Sunday. (Image credit: Jehad Alshrafi)

Title: Deadline passes without Gaza ceasefire going into effect
Description: The deadline for the start of a ceasefire in the Gaza Strip passed as Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Hamas had provided the names of the three hostages it was set to release on Sunday. (Image credit: Oded Balilty)

Title: Trump's border czar says immigration raids will begin next week, including in Chicago
Description: Prospects of a raid in Chicago come just a few weeks after Trump's border czar Tom Homan visited the city and threatened to prosecute the mayor if he did not cooperate. (Image credit: Jos Edelson)

Title: Trump says he'll likely give TikTok a 90-day extension
Description: President-elect Donald Trump spoke on the possibility of delaying a ban less than 24 hours from when the social media app is expected to shut down. (Image credit: Beata Zawrzel)

Washington, D.C., is celebrating MLK's birthday a little early this year
Description: Washington DC marks the birthday of Martin Luther King Junior a bit early, because of Monday's Presidential inauguration.

Title: The hydrants up here are dead.' Radio traffic shows how LA firefighters lost water
Description: NPR transcribed more than 2,000 hours of radio communications from the LA fires. It shows hydrants going dry and first responders fighting the fires despite scarce resources. (Image credit: Brian van der Brug)

Title: South Korean court orders formal arrest of President Yoon over martial law decree
Description: South Korea's impeached president, Yoon Suk Yeol, faces possible imprisonment over his declaration of martial law last month. The formal arrest comes days after he was apprehended. (Image credit: Ahn Young-joon)

Title: U.S. pays $590 million to Moderna to speed up development of bird flu vaccine
Description: The public health risk remains low, but bird flu variants have proven to be unpredictable, which is why the virus is a top priority for the federal government. (Image credit: Plexi Images)

Title: In India, a police volunteer is convicted of rape and murder of a trainee doctor
Description: A court found a police volunteer guilty of the rape and murder of a 31-year-old trainee doctor, a crime that sparked protests and hospital strikes amid concerns over lack of safety for women. (Image credit: Bikas Das)

Title: Israel approves a ceasefire deal with Hamas, set to go into effect Sunday
Description: The Israeli government approved a ceasefire deal that could bring an end to the 15 months of war in Gaza. It's slated to go into effect Sunday morning.

Title: In Syria, some celebrations are tempered by rising prices and scarcity
Description: Syrians are still celebrating the fall of the Bashar Al-Assad regime, but that enthusiasm is tempered these days.

Title: How outgoing Attorney General Merrick Garland fared in prosecuting war crimes
Description: We look at what the Department of Justice has and hasn't done on war crimes under outgoing Attorney General Merrick Garland.

Title: Trump has promised mass deportations. Why some migrants think it's worth the risk
Description: Even as an anti-immigrant president takes office in the United States, migrants are moving north. NPR asks, why?

Title: What the ceasefire deal could mean for Netanyahu and Israeli politics
Description: NPR's Scott Simon speaks with Yossi Mekelberg of Chatham House's Middle East and North Africa Program, about the Israeli political response to a negotiated ceasefire between Israel and Hamas.

Title: More teens say they're using ChatGPT for schoolwork, a new study finds
Description: According to the survey, 26% of students ages 13-17 are using the artificial intelligence bot to help them with their assignments. (Image credit: EyeEm Mobile GmbH)

Title: Private firefighters are helping out in LA wildfires. It raises ethical questions
Description: Insurers are deploying private firefighters amid the Los Angeles wildfires. Are they an added bonus for all — or only for those who can afford them? (Image credit: Justin Sullivan)

Title: In Lebanon, these Palestinian refugees sew designs from a homeland they've never seen
Description: In a workshop in an infamous refugee camp in Beirut, Palestinian women practice an ancient art form — as a livelihood, and also as therapy. The designs come from a homeland most have never seen. (Image credit: Dalia Khamissy for NPR)

Title: These are the U.S. citizens held hostage in Gaza
Description: Seven of the nearly 100 hostages held in Gaza are U.S. citizens, several of whom are confirmed dead. (Image credit: Hostages and Missing Families Forum)

Title: A California fifth grader interviews his firefighter father
Description: Cian Lawlor's father was dispatched to the Palisades Fire just over a week ago and he's been working it ever since. The 11-year-old had some questions for his dad. (Image credit: Jaleh Lawlor)

Title: Russian attack kills at least 3 people in Kyiv
Description: Russia attacked Ukraine's capital with a barrage of drones and missiles Saturday, leaving at least three people dead, while industrial sites in Russia were set ablaze by Ukrainian strikes. (Image credit: Efrem Lukatsky)

Title: Russian attack kills 4 people in Kyiv
Description: Russia attacked the Ukrainian capital with a barrage of drones and missiles Saturday, leaving at least four people dead, while industrial sites in Russia were set ablaze by Ukrainian strikes. (Image credit: Efrem Lukatsky)

Title: More than 40 Pakistani migrants feared drowned off African coast
Description: Pakistan said that the boat, carrying 80 passengers including some Pakistanis, had set off from Mauritania on their way to the Canary Islands. (Image credit: K.M. Chaudary)

Title: A South African horror story: illegal mining stand-off draws to an end
Description: In South Africa a months long stand-off between police and illegal miners in an abandoned gold mine comes to end, with close to 80 found dead in grim recovery operation. (Image credit: LINDA GIVETASH)

Title: A Dangerous Ride on Top of a Train in Mexico
Description: The incoming Trump administration has promised sweeping deportations of undocumented people and little empathy for those seeking refuge in the U.S. Despite that, migrants continue to make the dangerous journey north through Mexico to get to the U.S. border. We hop on a freight train with some migrants to find out why.

Title: The birds are back.' Resilience in the ruins of the Palisades fire
Description: Will Rogers State Historic Park is a vast stretch of natural space in the Santa Monica Mountains. It's a treasure to Angelenos. People get married there, picnic there, and have kids' birthday parties on the great lawn.The park's namesake, Will Rogers, was a vaudeville performer, radio and movie star, and was known as America's 'cowboy philosopher.' His nearly century-old ranch house is the park's centerpiece. It's survived a near miss with wildfire before. Description: Days before Donald Trump takes office with the promise of mass deportation, immigrants are bracing for Trump's potential first actions. Title: Immigrants and advocacy organizations brace for Trump's Day One actions
Description: Days before Donald Trump takes office with the promise of mass deportation, immigrants are bracing for Trump's first actions, including staying away from going to work, while immigrant advocacy organizations have launched 'know your rights' campaigns across the country.

Title: The long road to recovery for Israeli hostages
Description: Part of the cease-fire agreement between Israel and Hamas involves the return of Israeli hostages that have been held in Gaza for more than a year. Their families are relieved, but the hostages have a long road to recovery once they're back home.

Title: CNN liable of defamation for story on 'black market' evacuations from Afghanistan
Description: A Florida jury found CNN defamed a security consultant in a story that suggested he was charging 'exorbitant prices' to evacuate people trying to flee Afghanistan after the U.S. withdrawal in 2021. (Image credit: CNN via Internet Archive/Screenshot by NPR)

Title: Immigration is a lifeline for Nebraska's economy. But Trump's mass deportations pledge is a looming threat
Description: Nebraska is one of the top meat producers in the U.S. It also has one of the worst labor shortages. The incoming Trump administration has promised mass deportations on an unprecedented scale. We asked Nebraskans what that could mean. (Image credit: Lexi Parra)

Title: Pepsi accused of illegal pricing deals with 'a large, big box retailer' in U.S. lawsuit
Description: The Federal Trade Commission is suing Pepsi, alleging it has rigged competition by offering unfair pricing deals to a big retailer at the expense of smaller rivals, resulting in higher costs for shoppers. (Image credit: Michael M. Santiago)

Title: Trump's inauguration falls on MLK Day. That overlap is pretty rare
Description: Trump is only the third president to be sworn in on Martin Luther King Jr. Day. Due to the particulars of the calendar and the Constitution, the two events won't overlap again until 2053.

Title: Trump and China's Xi speak by phone as Supreme Court issues TikTok ruling
Description: The Trump-Xi phone call came hours before the Supreme Court on Friday upheld a U.S. law that effectively bans TikTok starting Sunday. (Image credit: Jeff Swensen/Getty Images; Greg Bowker/Getty Images.)

Title: Food pantries are bracing for more demand if the Trump administration cuts food aid
Description: The first Trump administration tried to scale back who gets food benefits, and allies aim to try again. Food pantries say they're already busier than ever. (Image credit: Dee Dwyer)

Title: Former Israeli ambassador to the U.S. discusses Israel-Hamas ceasefire
Description: Michael Oren, former Israeli ambassador to the U.S., joins NPR's Michel Martin to discuss Israel's security cabinet approving a Gaza ceasefire and hostage deal. The agreement still needs the full cabinet's OK.

Title: Fire at one of the world's largest battery plants forces evacuations in California
Description: A major fire erupted south of San Francisco at the Moss Landing Power Plant, forcing hundreds to evacuate. So far, the fire has stayed in the facility, which stores thousands of lithium batteries. (Image credit: KSBW)

Title: Israel's security cabinet approves Gaza ceasefire and hostage deal
Description: Israel's security cabinet has voted to approve a ceasefire deal to end the fighting in Gaza. Full cabinet approval is expected later today. (Image credit: Hasan N. H. Alzaanin)

Title: Next steps for Israel-Hamas ceasefire deal. And, polar vortex to envelop the U.S.
Description: The Israeli security cabinet meeting to vote on a ceasefire deal with Hamas, which was delayed yesterday, is set for today. And, frigid temperatures are expected to envelop much of the U.S. next week. (Image credit: Ariel Schalit)

Title: Some Los Angeles homes made it through the firestorm. Here's how
Description: Houses are still standing in the burn zone in Los Angeles, ones that made it through the fires. Experts on the ground are finding those homeowners made some key preparations. (Image credit: Mario Tama/Getty Images)

Title: A polar vortex is set to grip much of the U.S. What does that mean?
Description: Bundle up and prepare: People living 'basically anywhere from the Rockies eastward' will see extremely cold temperatures over the next several days, a meteorologist says. (Image credit: Nam Y. Huh)

Title: Development is taking a toll on Florida's precious springs
Description: The state has been slow to adopt rules to protect Florida's endangered springs. While a boom in residential construction has increased the amount of groundwater being taken from the aquifers. (Image credit: Zack Wittman for NPR)

Title: Why Australian Open live streams look like Wii tennis — and what it means for sports
Description: The Australian Open's animated tennis livestreams are making a splash. U.S. leagues have used similar technology to put Simpsons on the football field and superheroes on ice skates. (Image credit: Australian Open TV/Screenshot by NPR)

Title: What question stumped a Trump cabinet pick? Find out in the news quiz!
Description: If you've paid attention to the coming inauguration, TikTok drama and the Princess of Wales' health, you'll do pretty well this week.

Title: Court sentences former Pakistani leader Imran Khan to 14 years in prison
Description: Khan has denied wrongdoing and insisted since his arrest in 2023 that all the charges against him are a plot by rivals to keep him from returning to office. (Image credit: K.M. Chaudary)

Title: Palestinian National Initiative's Mustafa Barghouti discusses the ceasefire agreement
Description: Mustafa Barghouti, secretary-general of the Palestinian National Initiative, joins to discuss the latest developments on the Gaza ceasefire agreement between Israel and Hamas.

Description: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with the outgoing U.S. ambassador to China, Nicholas Burns. He says China faces certain challenges, like a slowing economy and a declining population.

Title: Mortgage rates have hit 7%. What should people searching for a home do?
Description: Mortgage rates have hit 7%. Mark Hamrick, Washington bureau chief for Bankrate, talks about what this means for borrowers and how this will affect the housing market.

Title: Hear the latest developments on the ceasefire agreement between Israel and Hamas
Description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu delayed a vote on a ceasefire agreement with Hamas, saying the group was making demands for a 'last minute concession.' Hear the latest developments.

Description: In the Los Angeles wildfires, private firefighters have been hired by insurance companies and wealthy residents to protect homes and businesses. We take a look at who they are and what they do.

Title: China's population falls for a third straight year, posing challenges for its economy
Description: Rising costs of living are causing young people to put off or rule out marriage and child birth while pursuing higher education and careers. (Image credit: Andy Wong)

Title: College campuses react to the news of the Israel-Hamas ceasefire deal
Description: The Israel-Hamas war ignited protests on many U.S. college campuses. Some students were elated, others concerned after the announcement of a ceasefire.

Title: ICE estimates it would need $26.9 billion to enforce GOP deportation bill
Description: An internal document from Immigration and Customs Enforcement concludes it would be 'impossible' for it to enforce the Laken Riley Act without significantly more resources. (Image credit: Pool)

Title: Trump's challenge: where to house millions of immigrant detainees
Description: One of the biggest hurdles to carrying out Trump's mass deportation plans is where to house the millions of people who are in the country without legal status. As many prisons and detention centers are already overcrowded, what options are there? (Image credit: Veronica Gabriela Cardenas)

Title: Trump nominee to lead HUD says the agency is failing in its mission
Description: Scott Turner pledged to make HUD programs more streamlined and efficient. He declined to say whether he would oppose major budget cuts to the agency if Trump proposes them again. (Image credit: Rod Lamkey)

Title: Angelenos who didn't have to evacuate are experiencing survivor's guilt from fires
Description: Most people in L.A. did not evacuate -- and many have survivor's guilt. Katia Riddle discusses with Ailsa strategies for Angelenos who are navigating this complicated emotional terrain.

Title: Will we finally see an end to the war in Gaza?
Description: At the time we publish this episode, Israel's government has yet to accept the terms of the long-negotiated and hard fought ceasefire deal announced yesterday.The deal is still on, but the quarreling over the details demonstrates how difficult it is to keep the agreement on track.On Thursday morning Israeli prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu delayed a cabinet vote on the deal, accusing Hamas of 'reneging' on parts of the agreement. A Hamas official said on social media that the group is committed to the agreement announced Wednesday. After more than 15 long months, tens of thousands dead, and close to 2 million people displaced, will we finally see an end to the war in Gaza? Title: Freezing temperatures are expected during Trump's second inauguration
Description: Monday's Inauguration Day is set to be the coldest in 40 years. The high temperature for the day is projected to be around freezing at 23 degrees, while the low for the day may drop to just 10 degrees. (Image credit: Kent Nishimura/Getty Images)

Title: Trump's pick for EPA administrator is Lee Zeldin. Here's what to know.
Description: Democrats worry the Trump administration will roll back efforts to limit climate change. (Image credit: Mark Schiefelbein/AP)

Title: Disputes arise in the Israel-Hamas ceasefire
Description: A day after an Israel-Hamas ceasefire agreement was announced, the two sides are quarreling over details. The deal is still on, but the dispute demonstrates how difficult it may be stay on track.

Title: Will Israel's Government Ratify the Gaza Ceasefire Deal?
Description: Just one day after the announcement of a deal between Israel and Hamas to end the war in Gaza, Israel's prime minister threatened to delay a cabinet vote to approve the deal. He later relented and scheduled a vote. To understand the politics behind the deal and how the U.S. will be involved in its implementation we hear from Aaron David Miller. He once represented the U.S. in peace negotiations in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. You can find all our reporting on this conflict at npr.org/mideastupdates

Title: Canadian man's home security camera captures the sight and sound of a meteorite strike
Description: Joe Velaidum's home security camera captured the instant a meteorite smashed against his home's brick walkway. The video is thought to be the first recorded sound of a meteorite's direct impact.

Title: The immigration journey: How long does it take to feel like an American?
Description: What does it take to feel like an American - and to be treated like one? Several communities shared their perspectives on the immigrant experience.

Title: Giuliani fails to appear for federal civil trial, says case has been settled
Description: Former New York City Mayor Rudolph Giuliani was scheduled to be a witness in a case set to determine which assets he would have to forfeit after he lied about two Georgia election workers. (Image credit: Alex Kent/Getty Images)

Title: LA's wildfires prompted a rash of fake images. Here's why
Description: It's not just that you're perpetrating a fraud' by spreading bogus images, expert Hany Farid says. The fakes also sow confusion about an ongoing catastrophe. (Image credit: @WTP_REPORT)

Title: A woman invented the rape kit. So why was a man given credit for it?
Description: Rape kits were widely known as 'Vitullo Kits' after a Chicago police sergeant. But a new book tells the story of Marty Goddard, a community activist who worked with runaway teenagers in the 1970s. (Image credit: Pat Sullivan)

Title: Biden issues an 11th hour executive order aimed at strengthening U.S. cybersecurity
Description: One of President Biden's final moves in office is aimed at shoring up critical infrastructure from cyberattacks. (Image credit: Drew Angerer)

Title: Russia tried to use the L.A. wildfires to spread anti-Ukraine propaganda
Description: Pro-Kremlin social media accounts and outlets have been spreading a baseless narrative that mansions belonging to Ukrainian officials burned down in Los Angeles. (Image credit: Mario Tama)
